Permutation test for correlation between two variables

Source: R/run_permutation_test_cor.R
run_permutation_test_cor.Rd

This function performs a permutation test to assess the significance of the correlation between two variables in a data frame. It computes the observed correlation, generates a null distribution of correlations by permuting one of the variables, and calculates an empirical p-value.

run_permutation_test_cor(
  df,
  x_var,
  y_var,
  B = 1000,
  method = "pearson",
  use = "complete.obs",
  workers = 1,
  seed = 1,
  drop_duplicates = FALSE,
  save_path = NULL,
  force_new = FALSE
)

Arguments

df

A data frame containing the variables of interest.

x_var

A string specifying the name of the first variable (e.g., "info_content").

y_var

A string specifying the name of the second variable (e.g., "n_cell_types_sig").

B

An integer specifying the number of permutations to perform (default is 1000).

method

A string specifying the correlation method to use ("pearson", "spearman", etc.; default is "pearson").

use

an optional character string giving a method for computing covariances in the presence of missing values. This must be (an abbreviation of) one of the strings "everything", "all.obs", "complete.obs", "na.or.complete", or "pairwise.complete.obs".

workers

An integer specifying the number of parallel workers to use (default is 1).

seed

An integer specifying the random seed for reproducibility (default is 1).

drop_duplicates

A logical indicating whether to drop duplicate (x_var, y_var) pairs before analysis (default is TRUE).

save_path

File path to cache results.

force_new

Ignore cached results.

Value

A data table containing the observed correlation, empirical p-value, and null distribution statistics.

Examples

# Example usage:
df <- data.frame(
  info_content = rnorm(100),
  n_cell_types_sig = rnorm(100)
)
result <- run_permutation_test_cor(
df, x_var="info_content", y_var="n_cell_types_sig", B = 1000)
#>
